bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, July 8, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg informs Hench that the Moran figure in Cornwell's painting has already been completed with a mustache. Plates of the painting have also already been made. He discusses the publication of an article on the painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, July 8, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
July 8, 1941
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
I just returned from my vacation and I had
a telephone call from Dean Cornwell saying that he had re-
ceived a telegram from you to the effect that Moran did not
have a mustache in Cuba.

Unfortunately, the plates have been made with
the mustache on. I don't think it makes much material diff-
erence.

I am enclosing two copies of the story which
appeared in the TIMES-PICAYUNE of New Orleans.

Late this month the NEW YORK SUNDAY MIRROR,
which is not a very high class publication, but which does
have a circulation of a million, four hundred thousand daily
and two million on Sunday will appear with “Conquerors of
Yellow Fever” in full color and with a story which will oc-
cupy two pages. I will send you a number of copies as soon
as it is out.

We shall have proofs of the reproductions of
the painting in about a week. I am sure that you will be in-
terested in seeing them.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Phillip S Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota.
